trans-unit.source: How to use diagnostics (.NET) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use diagnostics (.NET) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use diagnostic data in Azure for debugging, measuring performance, monitoring, traffic analysis, and more.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use diagnostic data in Azure for debugging, measuring performance, monitoring, traffic analysis, and more.

trans-unit.source: Enabling Diagnostics in Azure Cloud Services and Virtual Machines
trans-unit.target: Enabling Diagnostics in Azure Cloud Services and Virtual Machines

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 enable you to collect diagnostic data from a worker role, web role, or virtual machine running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 enable you to collect diagnostic data from a worker role, web role, or virtual machine running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This guide describes how to use Azure Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3.
trans-unit.target: This guide describes how to use Azure Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3.

trans-unit.source: For additional in-depth guidance on creating a logging and tracing strategy and using diagnostics and other techniques to troubleshoot problems, see <link><linkText>Troubleshooting Best Practices for Developing Azure Applications[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For additional in-depth guidance on creating a logging and tracing strategy and using diagnostics and other techniques to troubleshoot problems, see <link><linkText>Troubleshooting Best Practices for Developing Azure Applications[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 are Azure extensions that enable you to collect diagnostic telemetry data from a worker role, web role, or virtual machine running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 are Azure extensions that enable you to collect diagnostic telemetry data from a worker role, web role, or virtual machine running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The telemetry data is stored in an Azure storage account and can be used for debugging and troubleshooting, measuring performance, monitoring resource usage, traffic analysis and capacity planning, and auditing.
trans-unit.target: The telemetry data is stored in an Azure storage account and can be used for debugging and troubleshooting, measuring performance, monitoring resource usage, traffic analysis and capacity planning, and auditing.

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics 1.2 are for use with Azure SDKs for .NET 2.4 and before.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics 1.2 are for use with Azure SDKs for .NET 2.4 and before.

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics 1.3 are for use with Azure SDKs for .NET 2.5 and later.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics 1.3 are for use with Azure SDKs for .NET 2.5 and later.

trans-unit.source: If you have used Diagnostics version 1.0 in the past, there are three notable differences compared to Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3:
trans-unit.target: If you have used Diagnostics version 1.0 in the past, there are three notable differences compared to Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3:

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 can be deployed on virtual machines, in addition to cloud services.
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 can be deployed on virtual machines, in addition to cloud services.

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics 1.0 is part of the Azure SDK and is deployed when you deploy your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics 1.0 is part of the Azure SDK and is deployed when you deploy your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 are an extension and are deployed separately from your cloud service deployment.
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 are an extension and are deployed separately from your cloud service deployment.

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 enable the collection of ETW and .NET EventSource events.
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics 1.2 and 1.3 enable the collection of ETW and .NET EventSource events.

trans-unit.source: For a more detailed comparison, see <link><linkText>Comparing Azure Diagnostics Versions[]</linkText><title></title></link> at the end of this article.
trans-unit.target: For a more detailed comparison, see <link><linkText>Comparing Azure Diagnostics Versions[]</linkText><title></title></link> at the end of this article.

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics can collect the following types of telemetry:
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics can collect the following types of telemetry:

trans-unit.source: Data Source
trans-unit.target: Data Source

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: IIS Logs
trans-unit.target: IIS Logs

trans-unit.source: Information about IIS web sites.
trans-unit.target: Information about IIS web sites.

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostic infrastructure logs
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostic infrastructure logs

trans-unit.source: Information about Diagnostics itself.
trans-unit.target: Information about Diagnostics itself.

trans-unit.source: IIS Failed Request logs
trans-unit.target: IIS Failed Request logs

trans-unit.source: Information about failed requests to an IIS site or application.
trans-unit.target: Information about failed requests to an IIS site or application.

trans-unit.source: Windows Event logs
trans-unit.target: Windows Event logs

trans-unit.source: Information sent to the Windows event logging system.
trans-unit.target: Information sent to the Windows event logging system.

trans-unit.source: Performance counters
trans-unit.target: Performance counters

trans-unit.source: Operating System and custom performance counters.
trans-unit.target: Operating System and custom performance counters.

trans-unit.source: Crash dumps
trans-unit.target: Crash dumps

trans-unit.source: Information about the state of the process in the event of an application crash.
trans-unit.target: Information about the state of the process in the event of an application crash.

trans-unit.source: Custom error logs
trans-unit.target: Custom error logs

trans-unit.source: Logs created by your application or service.
trans-unit.target: Logs created by your application or service.

trans-unit.source: NET EventSource
trans-unit.target: NET EventSource

trans-unit.source: Events generated by your code using the .NET <html></html>EventSource class<html></html>
trans-unit.target: Events generated by your code using the .NET <html></html>EventSource class<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Manifest based ETW
trans-unit.target: Manifest based ETW

trans-unit.source: ETW events generated by any process.
trans-unit.target: ETW events generated by any process.

trans-unit.source: How to Enable Diagnostics in a Worker Role
trans-unit.target: How to Enable Diagnostics in a Worker Role

trans-unit.source: This walk through describes how to implement an Azure worker role that emits telemetry data using the .NET EventSource class.
trans-unit.target: This walk through describes how to implement an Azure worker role that emits telemetry data using the .NET EventSource class.

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics is used to collect the telemetry data and store it in an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics is used to collect the telemetry data and store it in an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: When creating a worker role Visual Studio automatically enables Diagnostics 1.0 as part of the solution in Azure SDKs for .NET 2.4 and earlier.
trans-unit.target: When creating a worker role Visual Studio automatically enables Diagnostics 1.0 as part of the solution in Azure SDKs for .NET 2.4 and earlier.

trans-unit.source: The following instructions describe the process for creating the worker role, disabling Diagnostics 1.0 from the solution, and deploying Diagnostics 1.2 or 1.3 to your worker role.
trans-unit.target: The following instructions describe the process for creating the worker role, disabling Diagnostics 1.0 from the solution, and deploying Diagnostics 1.2 or 1.3 to your worker role.

trans-unit.source: Pre-requisites
trans-unit.target: Pre-requisites

trans-unit.source: This article assumes you have an Azure subscription and are using Visual Studio 2013 with the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: This article assumes you have an Azure subscription and are using Visual Studio 2013 with the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have an Azure subscription, you can sign up for the <link><linkText>Free Trial[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have an Azure subscription, you can sign up for the <link><linkText>Free Trial[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to <link><linkText>Install and configure Azure PowerShell version 0.8.7 or later[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to <link><linkText>Install and configure Azure PowerShell version 0.8.7 or later[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a Worker Role
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a Worker Role

trans-unit.source: Launch Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: Launch Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Azure Cloud Service project from the Cloud template that targets .NET Framework 4.5.
trans-unit.target: Create a new Azure Cloud Service project from the Cloud template that targets .NET Framework 4.5.

trans-unit.source: Name the project "WadExample" and click Ok.
trans-unit.target: Name the project "WadExample" and click Ok.

trans-unit.source: Select Worker Role and click Ok.
trans-unit.target: Select Worker Role and click Ok.

trans-unit.source: The project will be created.
trans-unit.target: The project will be created.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, double-click on the WorkerRole1 properties file.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click on the WorkerRole1 properties file.

trans-unit.source: In the Configuration tab un-check Enable Diagnostics to disable Diagnostics 1.0 (Azure SDK 2.4 and eariler).
trans-unit.target: In the Configuration tab un-check Enable Diagnostics to disable Diagnostics 1.0 (Azure SDK 2.4 and eariler).

trans-unit.source: Build your solution to verify that you have no errors.
trans-unit.target: Build your solution to verify that you have no errors.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Instrument your code
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Instrument your code

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of WorkerRole.cs with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of WorkerRole.cs with the following code.

trans-unit.source: The class SampleEventSourceWriter, inherited from the EventSource Class[], implements four logging methods: SendEnums, MessageMethod, SetOther and HighFreq.
trans-unit.target: The class SampleEventSourceWriter, inherited from the EventSource Class[], implements four logging methods: SendEnums, MessageMethod, SetOther and HighFreq.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter to the WriteEvent method defines the ID for the respective event.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter to the WriteEvent method defines the ID for the respective event.

trans-unit.source: The Run method implements an infinite loop that calls each of the logging methods implemented in the SampleEventSourceWriter class every 10 seconds.
trans-unit.target: The Run method implements an infinite loop that calls each of the logging methods implemented in the SampleEventSourceWriter class every 10 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Deploy your Worker Role
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Deploy your Worker Role

trans-unit.source: Deploy your worker role to Azure from within Visual Studio by selecting the WadExample project in the Solution Explorer then Publish from the Build menu.
trans-unit.target: Deploy your worker role to Azure from within Visual Studio by selecting the WadExample project in the Solution Explorer then Publish from the Build menu.

trans-unit.source: Choose your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Choose your subscription.

trans-unit.source: In the Microsoft Azure Publish Settings dialog select Create New….
trans-unit.target: In the Microsoft Azure Publish Settings dialog select Create New….

trans-unit.source: In the Create Cloud Service and Storage Account dialog enter a Name (for example, "WadExample") and select a region or affinity group.
trans-unit.target: In the Create Cloud Service and Storage Account dialog enter a Name (for example, "WadExample") and select a region or affinity group.

trans-unit.source: Set the Environment to Staging.
trans-unit.target: Set the Environment to Staging.

trans-unit.source: Modify any other Settings as appropriate and click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Modify any other Settings as appropriate and click Publish.

trans-unit.source: After deployment has completed verify in the Azure Portal that your cloud service is in a Running state.
trans-unit.target: After deployment has completed verify in the Azure Portal that your cloud service is in a Running state.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Create your Diagnostics configuration file and install the extension
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Create your Diagnostics configuration file and install the extension

trans-unit.source: Download the public configuration file schema definition by executing the following PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: Download the public configuration file schema definition by executing the following PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: (Get-AzureServiceAvailableExtension -ExtensionName 'PaaSDiagnostics' -ProviderNamespace 'Microsoft.Azure.Diagnostics').PublicConfigurationSchema | Out-File -Encoding utf8 -FilePath 'WadConfig.xsd'
trans-unit.target: (Get-AzureServiceAvailableExtension -ExtensionName 'PaaSDiagnostics' -ProviderNamespace 'Microsoft.Azure.Diagnostics').PublicConfigurationSchema | Out-File -Encoding utf8 -FilePath 'WadConfig.xsd'

trans-unit.source: Add an XML file to your WorkerRole1 project by right-clicking on the WorkerRole1 project and select Add -> New Item… -> Visual C# items -> Data -> XML File.
trans-unit.target: Add an XML file to your WorkerRole1 project by right-clicking on the WorkerRole1 project and select Add -> New Item… -> Visual C# items -> Data -> XML File.

trans-unit.source: Name the file "WadExample.xml".
trans-unit.target: Name the file "WadExample.xml".

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CloudServices_diag_add_xml</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CloudServices_diag_add_xml</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Associate the WadConfig.xsd with the configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Associate the WadConfig.xsd with the configuration file.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the WadExample.xml editor window is the active window.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the WadExample.xml editor window is the active window.

trans-unit.source: Press F4 to open the Properties window.
trans-unit.target: Press F4 to open the Properties window.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Schemas property in the Properties window.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Schemas property in the Properties window.

trans-unit.source: Click the … in the Schemas property.
trans-unit.target: Click the … in the Schemas property.

trans-unit.source: Click the Add… button and navigate to the location where you saved the XSD file and select the file WadConfig.xsd.
trans-unit.target: Click the Add… button and navigate to the location where you saved the XSD file and select the file WadConfig.xsd.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of the WadExample.xml configuration file with the following XML and save the file.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of the WadExample.xml configuration file with the following XML and save the file.

trans-unit.source: This configuration file defines a couple performance counters to collect: one for CPU utilization and one for memory utilization.
trans-unit.target: This configuration file defines a couple performance counters to collect: one for CPU utilization and one for memory utilization.

trans-unit.source: Then the configuration defines the four events corresponding to the methods in the SampleEventSourceWriter class.
trans-unit.target: Then the configuration defines the four events corresponding to the methods in the SampleEventSourceWriter class.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Install Diagnostics on your Worker Role
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Install Diagnostics on your Worker Role

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell cmdlets for managing Diagnostics on a web or worker role are: Set-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension, Get-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension, and Remove-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell cmdlets for managing Diagnostics on a web or worker role are: Set-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension, Get-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension, and Remove-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension.

trans-unit.source: Open Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Open Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Execute the script to install Diagnostics on your worker role (replace StorageAccountKey with the storage account key for your wadexample storage account):
trans-unit.target: Execute the script to install Diagnostics on your worker role (replace StorageAccountKey with the storage account key for your wadexample storage account):

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Look at your telemetry data
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Look at your telemetry data

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio Server Explorer navigate to the wadexample storage account.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio Server Explorer navigate to the wadexample storage account.

trans-unit.source: After the cloud service has been running about 5 minutes you should see the tables WADEnumsTable, WADHighFreqTable, WADMessageTable, WADPerformanceCountersTable and WADSetOtherTable.
trans-unit.target: After the cloud service has been running about 5 minutes you should see the tables WADEnumsTable, WADHighFreqTable, WADMessageTable, WADPerformanceCountersTable and WADSetOtherTable.

trans-unit.source: Double-click on one of the tables to view the telemetry that has been collected.
trans-unit.target: Double-click on one of the tables to view the telemetry that has been collected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CloudServices_diag_tables</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CloudServices_diag_tables</linkText>

trans-unit.source: How to Enable Diagnostics in a Virtual Machine
trans-unit.target: How to Enable Diagnostics in a Virtual Machine

trans-unit.source: This walk through describes how to remotely install Diagnostics to an Azure virtual machine from a development computer.
trans-unit.target: This walk through describes how to remotely install Diagnostics to an Azure virtual machine from a development computer.

trans-unit.source: You also learn how to implement an application that runs on that Azure virtual machine and emits telemetry data using the .NET <link><linkText>EventSource Class[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You also learn how to implement an application that runs on that Azure virtual machine and emits telemetry data using the .NET <link><linkText>EventSource Class[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics is used to collect the telemetry and store it in an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics is used to collect the telemetry and store it in an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Pre-requisites
trans-unit.target: Pre-requisites

trans-unit.source: This walk through assumes you have an Azure subscription and are using Visual Studio 2013 with the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: This walk through assumes you have an Azure subscription and are using Visual Studio 2013 with the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have an Azure subscription, you can sign up for the <link><linkText>Free Trial[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have an Azure subscription, you can sign up for the <link><linkText>Free Trial[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to <link><linkText>Install and configure Azure PowerShell version 0.8.7 or later[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to <link><linkText>Install and configure Azure PowerShell version 0.8.7 or later[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create a Virtual Machine
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create a Virtual Machine

trans-unit.source: On your development computer, launch Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: On your development computer, launch Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio Server Explorer expand Azure, right-click Virtual Machines then select Create Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio Server Explorer expand Azure, right-click Virtual Machines then select Create Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: Select your Azure subscription in the Choose a Subscription dialog and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Select your Azure subscription in the Choose a Subscription dialog and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Select Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter, November 2014 in the Select a Virtual Machine Image dialog and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Select Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter, November 2014 in the Select a Virtual Machine Image dialog and click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the Virtual Machine Basic Settings, set the virtual machine name to "wadexample".
trans-unit.target: In the Virtual Machine Basic Settings, set the virtual machine name to "wadexample".

trans-unit.source: Set your Administrator user name and password and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Set your Administrator user name and password and click Next.

trans-unit.source: In the Cloud Service Settings dialog create a new cloud service named "wadexampleVM".
trans-unit.target: In the Cloud Service Settings dialog create a new cloud service named "wadexampleVM".

trans-unit.source: Create a new Storage account named "wadexample" and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Create a new Storage account named "wadexample" and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create your Application
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create your Application

trans-unit.source: On your development computer, launch Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: On your development computer, launch Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Create a new Visual C# Console Application that targets .NET Framework 4.5.
trans-unit.target: Create a new Visual C# Console Application that targets .NET Framework 4.5.

trans-unit.source: Name the project "WadExampleVM".
trans-unit.target: Name the project "WadExampleVM".

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CloudServices_diag_new_project</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CloudServices_diag_new_project</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of Program.cs with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of Program.cs with the following code.

trans-unit.source: The class SampleEventSourceWriter implements four logging methods: SendEnums, MessageMethod, SetOther and HighFreq.
trans-unit.target: The class SampleEventSourceWriter implements four logging methods: SendEnums, MessageMethod, SetOther and HighFreq.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter to the WriteEvent method defines the ID for the respective event.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter to the WriteEvent method defines the ID for the respective event.

trans-unit.source: The Run method implements an infinite loop that calls each of the logging methods implemented in the SampleEventSourceWriter class every 10 seconds.
trans-unit.target: The Run method implements an infinite loop that calls each of the logging methods implemented in the SampleEventSourceWriter class every 10 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Save the file and select Build Solution from the Build menu to build your code.
trans-unit.target: Save the file and select Build Solution from the Build menu to build your code.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Deploy your Application
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Deploy your Application

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the WadExampleVM project in Solution Explorer and choose Open Folder in File Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the WadExampleVM project in Solution Explorer and choose Open Folder in File Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the bin\Debug folder and copy all the files (WadExampleVM.*)
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the bin\Debug folder and copy all the files (WadExampleVM.*)

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer right-click on the virtual machine and choose Connect using Remote Desktop.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer right-click on the virtual machine and choose Connect using Remote Desktop.

trans-unit.source: Once connected to the VM create a folder named WadExampleVM and paste your application files into the folder.
trans-unit.target: Once connected to the VM create a folder named WadExampleVM and paste your application files into the folder.

trans-unit.source: Launch the application WadExampleVM.exe.
trans-unit.target: Launch the application WadExampleVM.exe.

trans-unit.source: You should see a blank console window.
trans-unit.target: You should see a blank console window.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Create your Diagnostics configuration and install the Extension
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Create your Diagnostics configuration and install the Extension

trans-unit.source: Download the public configuration file schema definition to your development computer by executing the following PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: Download the public configuration file schema definition to your development computer by executing the following PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: Open a new XML file in Visual Studio, either in a project you already have open or in a Visual Studio instance with no open projects.
trans-unit.target: Open a new XML file in Visual Studio, either in a project you already have open or in a Visual Studio instance with no open projects.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, select Add -> New Item… -> Visual C# items -> Data -> XML File.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, select Add -> New Item… -> Visual C# items -> Data -> XML File.

trans-unit.source: Name the file "WadExample.xml"
trans-unit.target: Name the file "WadExample.xml"

trans-unit.source: Associate the WadConfig.xsd with the configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Associate the WadConfig.xsd with the configuration file.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the WadExample.xml editor window is the active window.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the WadExample.xml editor window is the active window.

trans-unit.source: Press F4 to open the Properties window.
trans-unit.target: Press F4 to open the Properties window.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Schemas property in the Properties window.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Schemas property in the Properties window.

trans-unit.source: Click the … in the Schemas property.
trans-unit.target: Click the … in the Schemas property.

trans-unit.source: Click the Add… button and navigate to the location where you saved the XSD file and select the file WadConfig.xsd.
trans-unit.target: Click the Add… button and navigate to the location where you saved the XSD file and select the file WadConfig.xsd.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of the WadExample.xml configuration file with the following XML and save the file.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of the WadExample.xml configuration file with the following XML and save the file.

trans-unit.source: This configuration file defines a couple performance counters to collect: one for CPU utilization and one for memory utilization.
trans-unit.target: This configuration file defines a couple performance counters to collect: one for CPU utilization and one for memory utilization.

trans-unit.source: Then the configuration defines the four events corresponding to the methods in the SampleEventSourceWriter class.
trans-unit.target: Then the configuration defines the four events corresponding to the methods in the SampleEventSourceWriter class.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Remotely install Diagnostics on your Azure Virtual Machine
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Remotely install Diagnostics on your Azure Virtual Machine

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell cmdlets for managing Diagnostics on a VM are: Set-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension, Get-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension, and Remove-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell cmdlets for managing Diagnostics on a VM are: Set-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension, Get-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension, and Remove-AzureVMDiagnosticsExtension.

trans-unit.source: On your developer computer, open Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: On your developer computer, open Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Execute the script to remotely install Diagnostics on your VM (Replace StorageAccountKey with the storage account key for your wadexamplevm storage account):
trans-unit.target: Execute the script to remotely install Diagnostics on your VM (Replace StorageAccountKey with the storage account key for your wadexamplevm storage account):

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Look at your telemetry data
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Look at your telemetry data

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio Server Explorer navigate to the wadexample storage account.
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio Server Explorer navigate to the wadexample storage account.

trans-unit.source: After the VM has been running about 5 minutes you should see the tables WADEnumsTable, WADHighFreqTable, WADMessageTable, WADPerformanceCountersTable and WADSetOtherTable.
trans-unit.target: After the VM has been running about 5 minutes you should see the tables WADEnumsTable, WADHighFreqTable, WADMessageTable, WADPerformanceCountersTable and WADSetOtherTable.

trans-unit.source: Double-click on one of the tables to view the telemetry that has been collected.
trans-unit.target: Double-click on one of the tables to view the telemetry that has been collected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CloudServices_diag_wadexamplevm_tables</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CloudServices_diag_wadexamplevm_tables</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Configuration File Schema
trans-unit.target: Configuration File Schema

trans-unit.source: The Diagnostics configuration file defines values that are used to initialize diagnostic configuration settings when the diagnostics monitor starts.
trans-unit.target: The Diagnostics configuration file defines values that are used to initialize diagnostic configuration settings when the diagnostics monitor starts.

trans-unit.source: A sample configuration file and detailed documentation on its schema is located here: <link><linkText>Azure Diagnostics 1.2 Configuration Schema[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: A sample configuration file and detailed documentation on its schema is located here: <link><linkText>Azure Diagnostics 1.2 Configuration Schema[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics is not Starting
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics is not Starting

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics is comprised of two components: A guest agent plugin and the monitoring agent.
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics is comprised of two components: A guest agent plugin and the monitoring agent.

trans-unit.source: Log files for the guest agent plugin are located in the file:
trans-unit.target: Log files for the guest agent plugin are located in the file:

trans-unit.source: *%SystemDrive%\ WindowsAzure\Logs\Plugins\Microsoft.Azure.Diagnostics.PaaSDiagnostics\<html></html>*\CommandExecution.log
trans-unit.target: *%SystemDrive%\ WindowsAzure\Logs\Plugins\Microsoft.Azure.Diagnostics.PaaSDiagnostics\<html></html>*\CommandExecution.log

trans-unit.source: The following error codes are returned by the plugin:
trans-unit.target: The following error codes are returned by the plugin:

trans-unit.source: Exit Code
trans-unit.target: Exit Code

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Success.
trans-unit.target: Success.

trans-unit.source: Generic Error.
trans-unit.target: Generic Error.

trans-unit.source: Unable to load the rcf file.<html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the guest agent plugin launcher is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.
trans-unit.target: Unable to load the rcf file.<html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the guest agent plugin launcher is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.

trans-unit.source: Cannot load the Diagnostics configuration file.<html></html><html></html>Solution: This is the result of a configuration file not passing schema validation. The solution is to provide a configuration file that complies with the schema.
trans-unit.target: Cannot load the Diagnostics configuration file.<html></html><html></html>Solution: This is the result of a configuration file not passing schema validation. The solution is to provide a configuration file that complies with the schema.

trans-unit.source: Another instance of the monitoring agent Diagnostics is already using the local resource directory.Solution: Specify a different value for LocalResourceDirectory.
trans-unit.target: Another instance of the monitoring agent Diagnostics is already using the local resource directory.Solution: Specify a different value for LocalResourceDirectory.

trans-unit.source: The guest agent plugin launcher attempted to launch Diagnostics with an invalid command line.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the guest agent plugin launcher is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.
trans-unit.target: The guest agent plugin launcher attempted to launch Diagnostics with an invalid command line.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the guest agent plugin launcher is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.

trans-unit.source: The Diagnostics plugin exited with an unhandled exception.
trans-unit.target: The Diagnostics plugin exited with an unhandled exception.

trans-unit.source: The guest agent was unable to create the process responsible for launching and monitoring the monitoring agent.<html></html><html></html>Solution: Verify that sufficient system resources are available to launch new processes.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: The guest agent was unable to create the process responsible for launching and monitoring the monitoring agent.<html></html><html></html>Solution: Verify that sufficient system resources are available to launch new processes.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Invalid arguments when calling the Diagnostics plugin.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the guest agent plugin launcher is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.
trans-unit.target: Invalid arguments when calling the Diagnostics plugin.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the guest agent plugin launcher is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.

trans-unit.source: The plugin process is unable to initialize itself.<html></html><html></html>Solution: Verify that sufficient system resources are available to launch new processes.
trans-unit.target: The plugin process is unable to initialize itself.<html></html><html></html>Solution: Verify that sufficient system resources are available to launch new processes.

trans-unit.source: The plugin process is unable to initialize itself. Specifically it is unable to create the logger object.<html></html><html></html>Solution: Verify that sufficient system resources are available to launch new processes.
trans-unit.target: The plugin process is unable to initialize itself. Specifically it is unable to create the logger object.<html></html><html></html>Solution: Verify that sufficient system resources are available to launch new processes.

trans-unit.source: Unable to load the rcf file provided by the guest agent.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the guest agent plugin launcher is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.
trans-unit.target: Unable to load the rcf file provided by the guest agent.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the guest agent plugin launcher is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.

trans-unit.source: The Diagnostics plugin cannot open the Diagnostics configuration file.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the Diagnostics plugin is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.
trans-unit.target: The Diagnostics plugin cannot open the Diagnostics configuration file.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the Diagnostics plugin is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.

trans-unit.source: Cannot read the Diagnostics configuration file.Solution: This is the result of a configuration file not passing schema validation. So the solution is to provide a configuration file that complies with the schema. You can find the XML that is delivered to the Diagnostics extension in the folder %SystemDrive%\WindowsAzure\Config on the VM. Open the appropriate XML file and search for Microsoft.Azure.Diagnostics, then for the xmlCfg field. The data is base64 encoded so you’ll need to decode it to see the XML that was loaded by Diagnostics.
trans-unit.target: Cannot read the Diagnostics configuration file.Solution: This is the result of a configuration file not passing schema validation. So the solution is to provide a configuration file that complies with the schema. You can find the XML that is delivered to the Diagnostics extension in the folder %SystemDrive%\WindowsAzure\Config on the VM. Open the appropriate XML file and search for Microsoft.Azure.Diagnostics, then for the xmlCfg field. The data is base64 encoded so you’ll need to decode it to see the XML that was loaded by Diagnostics.

trans-unit.source: The resource directory pass to the monitoring agent is invalid.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the monitoring agent is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: The resource directory pass to the monitoring agent is invalid.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the monitoring agent is manually invoked, incorrectly, on the VM.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Unable to convert the Diagnostics configuration file into the monitoring agent configuration file.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the Diagnostics plugin is manually invoked with an invalid configuration file.
trans-unit.target: Unable to convert the Diagnostics configuration file into the monitoring agent configuration file.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the Diagnostics plugin is manually invoked with an invalid configuration file.

trans-unit.source: General Diagnostics configuration error.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the Diagnostics plugin is manually invoked with an invalid configuration file.
trans-unit.target: General Diagnostics configuration error.<html></html><html></html>This is an internal error that should only happen if the Diagnostics plugin is manually invoked with an invalid configuration file.

trans-unit.source: Unable to start the monitoring agent.<html></html><html></html>Solution: Verify that sufficient system resources are available.
trans-unit.target: Unable to start the monitoring agent.<html></html><html></html>Solution: Verify that sufficient system resources are available.

trans-unit.source: General error
trans-unit.target: General error

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics Data is Not Logged to Storage
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics Data is Not Logged to Storage

trans-unit.source: The most common cause of missing event data is incorrectly defined storage account information.
trans-unit.target: The most common cause of missing event data is incorrectly defined storage account information.

trans-unit.source: Solution: Correct your Diagnostics configuration file and re-install Diagnostics.
trans-unit.target: Solution: Correct your Diagnostics configuration file and re-install Diagnostics.

trans-unit.source: Before event data is uploaded to your storage account it is stored in the folder.
trans-unit.target: Before event data is uploaded to your storage account it is stored in the folder.

trans-unit.source: See above for details on LocalResourceDirectory.
trans-unit.target: See above for details on LocalResourceDirectory.

trans-unit.source: If there are no files in this folder the monitoring agent is unable to launch.
trans-unit.target: If there are no files in this folder the monitoring agent is unable to launch.

trans-unit.source: This is typically caused by an invalid configuration file and should have been reported in the CommandExecution.log.
trans-unit.target: This is typically caused by an invalid configuration file and should have been reported in the CommandExecution.log.

trans-unit.source: If the Monitoring Agent is successfully collecting event data you will see .tsf files for each event defined in your configuration file.
trans-unit.target: If the Monitoring Agent is successfully collecting event data you will see .tsf files for each event defined in your configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The Monitoring Agent logs any errors it experiences in the file MaEventTable.tsf.
trans-unit.target: The Monitoring Agent logs any errors it experiences in the file MaEventTable.tsf.

trans-unit.source: To inspect the contents of this file run the following command:
trans-unit.target: To inspect the contents of this file run the following command:

trans-unit.source: The tool generates a file named maeventtable.csv that you may open and inspect the logs for failures.
trans-unit.target: The tool generates a file named maeventtable.csv that you may open and inspect the logs for failures.

trans-unit.source: Frequently Asked Questions
trans-unit.target: Frequently Asked Questions

trans-unit.source: The following are some frequently asked questions and their answers:
trans-unit.target: The following are some frequently asked questions and their answers:

trans-unit.source: Q. How do I upgrade my Visual Studio solution from Azure Diagnostics 1.0 to Azure Diagnostics 1.1?
trans-unit.target: Q. How do I upgrade my Visual Studio solution from Azure Diagnostics 1.0 to Azure Diagnostics 1.1?

trans-unit.source: A. Upgrading your Visual Studio solution from Diagnostics 1.0 to Diagnostics 1.1 (or later) is a manual process:
trans-unit.target: A. Upgrading your Visual Studio solution from Diagnostics 1.0 to Diagnostics 1.1 (or later) is a manual process:

trans-unit.source: Disable Diagnostics in your Visual Studio solution to prevent Diagnostics 1.0 from being deployed with your role
trans-unit.target: Disable Diagnostics in your Visual Studio solution to prevent Diagnostics 1.0 from being deployed with your role

trans-unit.source: If your code uses Trace Listener you will need to modify your code to use .NET EventSource.
trans-unit.target: If your code uses Trace Listener you will need to modify your code to use .NET EventSource.

trans-unit.source: Diagnostics 1.1 and later does not support Trace Listener.
trans-unit.target: Diagnostics 1.1 and later does not support Trace Listener.

trans-unit.source: Modify your deployment process to install the Diagnostics 1.1 extension
trans-unit.target: Modify your deployment process to install the Diagnostics 1.1 extension

trans-unit.source: Q. If I have already installed the Diagnostics 1.1 Extension on my role or VM how do I upgrade to Diagnostics 1.2 or 1.3?
trans-unit.target: Q. If I have already installed the Diagnostics 1.1 Extension on my role or VM how do I upgrade to Diagnostics 1.2 or 1.3?

trans-unit.source: A. If you specified “–Version “1.”" when you installed Diagnostics 1.1, the next time your role restarts or the VM reboots it will be automatically updated to the most recent version matching the regular expression “1.” If “–Version “1.1”” when you installed Diagnostics 1.1 you can update a newer version be re-executing the Set- cmdlet and specifying the version you want to install.
trans-unit.target: A. If you specified “–Version “1.”" when you installed Diagnostics 1.1, the next time your role restarts or the VM reboots it will be automatically updated to the most recent version matching the regular expression “1.” If “–Version “1.1”” when you installed Diagnostics 1.1 you can update a newer version be re-executing the Set- cmdlet and specifying the version you want to install.

trans-unit.source: Q. How are tables named?
trans-unit.target: Q. How are tables named?

trans-unit.source: A. Tables are named according to the following:
trans-unit.target: A. Tables are named according to the following:

trans-unit.source: Here is an example:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example:

trans-unit.source: That will generate 4 tables:
trans-unit.target: That will generate 4 tables:

trans-unit.source: Event
trans-unit.target: Event

trans-unit.source: Table Name
trans-unit.target: Table Name

trans-unit.source: provider=”prov1” <Event id=”1” />
trans-unit.target: provider=”prov1” <Event id=”1” />

trans-unit.source: WADEvent+MD5(“prov1”)+”1”
trans-unit.target: WADEvent+MD5(“prov1”)+”1”

trans-unit.source: provider=”prov1” <Event id=”2” eventDestination=”dest1” />
trans-unit.target: provider=”prov1” <Event id=”2” eventDestination=”dest1” />

trans-unit.source: WADdest1
trans-unit.target: WADdest1

trans-unit.source: provider=”prov1” <DefaultEvents />
trans-unit.target: provider=”prov1” <DefaultEvents />

trans-unit.source: WADDefault+MD5(“prov1”)
trans-unit.target: WADDefault+MD5(“prov1”)

trans-unit.source: provider=”prov2” <DefaultEvents eventDestination=”dest2” />
trans-unit.target: provider=”prov2” <DefaultEvents eventDestination=”dest2” />

trans-unit.source: WADdest2
trans-unit.target: WADdest2
